results.snippet: 'JOHN TARTAGLIA'S IMAGINOCEAN'      Not many shows in Manhattan ask you to sit down, then shower you twice with bubbles and spritz you with water. At times during ''John Tartaglia's Imaginocean,'' it's hard not to feel kidnapped by a carwash.
results.lead_paragraph: 'JOHN TARTAGLIA'S IMAGINOCEAN' Not many shows in Manhattan ask you to sit down, then shower you twice with bubbles and spritz you with water. At times during ''John Tartaglia's Imaginocean,'' it's hard not to feel kidnapped by a carwash.

results.abstract: Article in series Smarter Than You Think, examining recent advances in artificial intelligence and robotics and their potential impact on society, focuses on efforts by computer scientists to develop highly programmed robots that can teach people simple skills; most teaching robots are still very basic, but advanced models are fully autonomous, guided by motion tracking and speech recognition software; goal is to develop highly informed instructors that can teach both complex subjects and repetitive skill training; several countries including South Korea are already testing teaching machines in classrooms; diagrams; photos (M)

headline.main: Students, Meet Your New Teacher, Mr. Robot

results.snippet: Computer scientists are developing machines that can teach people simple skills, like household tasks and vocabulary.
results.section_name: Technology; Front Page; Education; Health; U.S.

byline.original: By BENEDICT CAREY and JOHN MARKOFF; Choe Sang-Hun contributed reporting from Seoul

results.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES -- The boy, a dark-haired 6-year-old, is playing with a new companion. The two hit it off quickly -- unusual for the 6-year-old, who has autism -- and the boy is imitating his playmate's every move, now nodding his head, now raising his arms.

results.snippet: A selected guide to events by and for children in the New York area.
results.lead_paragraph: 'FUN WITH CHICKENS!' For many New York City children, handling chicken means grabbing a nugget and swiping it through a trail of barbecue sauce. But on Sunday young residents will have a chance to pick up chickens that have never been near a stove -- and never will.

headline.main: New Mission for American Aerospace Giants

results.snippet: The commercialization of U.S. space policy proposed by President Obama means a major change in mission for aerospace contractors like Boeing and Lockheed Martin.
results.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK -- For Boeing, Lockheed Martin and the other aerospace giants that have been the backbone of the American space effort for decades, the shift in U.S. space policy announced by President Barack Obama means a major change in mission. After working for decades with largely one customer -- the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration -- to ferry astronauts and equipment into orbit, major players in the aerospace industry are facing a commercial market with a range of entrepreneurs who say they can do that work for less.

results.abstract: President Obama is expected to criticize the Republican stance on an extension of unemployment benefits this morning.

headline.main: The Early Word: Battle Over Benefits

results.snippet: President Obama is expected to criticize the Republican stance on an extension of unemployment benefits this morning.
results.lead_paragraph: President Obama is expected to make a Rose Garden statement Monday morning blasting Republicans for standing in the way of an extension of unemployment benefits that has been stalled in the Senate.

results.snippet: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) CLASH OF THE CONTINENTS The scenario: an astronaut passes through a space-time warp that returns him to Earth after 250 million years, above. What would he see? This new series consults with experts about the past so as...
results.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) CLASH OF THE CONTINENTS The scenario: an astronaut passes through a space-time warp that returns him to Earth after 250 million years, above. What would he see? This new series consults with experts about the past so as to better predict the future, including the natural forces that could put an end to human civilization and bring Earth full circle. The journey begins as scientists imagine a brave new world in the form of a supercontinent created by the planet's land masses moving into a new position. At 10, the scientists speculate on whether our species will evolve -- or self-destruct. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE The Rev. Jesse Jackson discusses the forced resignation of Shirley Sherrod from the Department of Agriculture and its effect on race relations in America. The debate continues at 10:30 on CBS and ''Face the Nation'' with Abigail Thernstrom, vice chairwoman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights; Michael Eric Dyson, the Georgetown University sociologist; and Cornel West, the Princeton University professor.

results.abstract: Tiffany Montague used to fly spy planes and now she leads Google's efforts to put robots on the moon.
results.snippet: Tiffany Montague used to fly spy planes and now she leads Google's efforts to put robots on the moon.
results.lead_paragraph: Google, as you may know, runs a search engine and sells ads. How odd then that Tiffany Montague works at the company.
